item.title: One Of The Creepiest Games Of The Year Is Pure Vibes, No Jump Scares
item.content:encoded:
If you dig strolling through empty, abandoned places, immersing yourself in some backrooms vibes, and enjoying all that‚Äôs weird and liminal, then do I have a game to recommend for you. Dreamcore came out in January of this year and it‚Äôs a perfectly good time if you love spooky vibes but aren‚Äôt too jazzed about screaming monsters and jumpscares.

Developed by Montralulz, Dreamcore is a directionless, HUD-free wandersim that takes you through strange, abandoned levels that almost feel endless. The game intentionally tries to make you feel lost with its lack of clear-cut instructions on what to do. Strange symbols written on walls, seemingly innocuous signs, odd music, and audio cues are the only thing you‚Äôre given to figure out where to go and what to do.

The levels are so massive, in fact, that I‚Äôm thinking I might need to keep some graph paper nearby to map out these spaces. I‚Äôve only completed one level thus far, ‚ÄúDreampools‚Äù which is a labyrinth of tiled walls, random pools, and the uncanny use of diffused lighting that often makes those wild Cyberpunk 2077 mods or the odd bodycam-footage game look disturbingly close to reality.

And though the game has no jumpscares, it‚Äôs still plenty capable of freaking you out‚Äìespecially with some of the odd objects you‚Äôll come across, like a massive smiley-face ball that, while certainly not intimidating, just feels‚Ä¶wrong. Is it watching me?

With so few things to actually do in these spaces other than walk around, the real challenge here is not losing your mind and staying focused on slowly unraveling where you should go, following what looks interesting in the hope that you‚Äôll find something unique. It reminds me a bit of The Stanley Parable, but with far simpler environments and the narrative elements ripped out. You often have the sense you‚Äôre being watched, that maybe someone‚Äôs been here before, and that there‚Äôs something you should do, but you can‚Äôt quite put your finger on it.

There are currently three worlds to explore: the aforementioned ‚ÄúDreampools,‚Äù an endless expanse of empty suburban homes and white picket fences in ‚ÄúEternal Suburbia,‚Äù and ‚ÄúPlayrooms,‚Äù described as ‚Äúa sequence of spaces inspired by children‚Äôs play areas, recreated with an artificial and silent aesthetic.‚Äù More levels are on the way.

So if the spooky season has you in the mood for exploring some creepy spaces without things screaming in your face, and you like a bit of the avant garde, Dreamcore might just be up your alley.

item.title: 13 Things To Know Before Starting Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A
item.content:encoded:
Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A makes some pretty notable changes to the series‚Äô typical formula. Its battles take place in real-time, it makes the Mega Evolution mechanic a cooldown, and it has several different mission types to juggle while you‚Äôre catching and training monsters. That means even series veterans are starting from zero on some things, so before you head into Lumiose City, here are a few helpful tips to make the most of your stay at Hotel Z.

Read up on Pok√©mon X and Y‚Äôs story

Legends: Z-A is essentially a direct sequel to 2013‚Äôs X and Y. The entire game takes place in Lumiose City, a Paris-inspired metropolis you pass through in the original 3DS RPGs. There are returning characters and storylines that come up in Legends: Z-A‚Äôs stories and sidequests, so if you‚Äôve never played through the original Kalos games or haven‚Äôt played them in a while, I recommend either reading a summary or watching a recap as a refresher. That way, you‚Äôll know why it‚Äôs significant that AZ is running your hotel, or that Emma has a full-time detective job, among other bigger reveals later on.

Prepare yourself: This game is handholdy for a while

Sometimes I wish Pok√©mon games would give me the option to interrupt NPCs with a Ron Swanson ‚ÄúI know more than you‚Äù when they insist on tutorializing every little thing. Like, aw, you think I don‚Äôt know what a Potion is, or that I‚Äôm not on a first-name basis with every Nurse Joy from here to Kanto? AndLegends: Z-A‚Äôs tutorial is particularly time-consuming, essentially taking up hours. You‚Äôll be dragged around the city by your companions for several in-game days as you‚Äôre taught the ins and outs of everything Legends: Z-A has to offer. Your Rotom phone will stop you from venturing too far from the intended path, and it will get very, very frustrating. But when it comes to an end, the rest of the city is open to you right off the bat.

Your moves do different things than you‚Äôre used to

Since Legends: Z-A has a real-time battle system, some classic attacks have been tweaked to fit this new setup. For example, buff moves that once affected your Pok√©mon for a certain number of turns are now calculated in real-time, lasting however many seconds rather than turns. As you teach your party new moves, familiarize yourself with how they work in Legends: Z-A, because they might be slightly different than what you‚Äôre used to.

Positioning and timing are everything

When you give your Pok√©mon commands, they will move to somewhere on the field that puts them in the right spot to execute the attack based on your opponent‚Äôs current position. However, if your opponent moves out of the way, the attack will miss. So rather than accuracy being determined by backend dice rolls, you see the attack land or not as you‚Äôre executing it. As such, a big part of learning how to best utilize every attack in your arsenal is understanding where you should be standing when you use it, and keeping an eye on your opponent‚Äôs maneuvers and cooldowns to make sure it‚Äôs timed well. Some enemies know moves like Protect that will shield them from your attacks, but they will be on a cooldown, so if you can bait your opponent into using it on a weaker move, you‚Äôll have an opening for a counterattack.

Find attack orders that act as combos

This new position-based gameplay means that simply attacking at random and cycling through your cooldowns is not always the best play. As you cultivate your Pok√©mon‚Äôs movesets, finding attacks that can synergize together to create combos can help you get the leg up on your opponents. For example, right now, my Pikachu knows Quick Attack, Nuzzle, and Spark. One of my go-to strategies in battles is to have him use Quick Attack to get in close to an enemy, use that closeness to Nuzzle them into a paralyzed state, then use Spark to run out of the fight with a destructive, electric dash. This combo lets Pikachu be a bit of a hit-and-run character that can get in, do some damage, then retreat to safety. Knowing how your moves can work together is just as important as type coverage, and discovering those will take some experimentation.

Stop locking on as a pseudo dodge

To target enemies on the field, you‚Äôll have to lock onto them with ZL. Doing this will make your active Pok√©mon square up against whoever you‚Äôre looking at, and they‚Äôll stay relatively close to this foe so they‚Äôre ready to execute any commands you give them. If you find your partner is getting slapped around and should get out of the scrap, simply stop locking onto an enemy, and your Pok√©mon will run back to your side. Make sure you‚Äôre also out of the way of whatever attack is incoming, too, though. 

You can reach any clothing store once you have free rein 

The fashion in Legends: Z-A is pretty great. It‚Äôs a definite upgrade from Scarlet and Violet, which forced all of us to wear school uniforms. New fits are expensive, but the game is pretty generous about letting you buy whatever clothes you want pretty quickly. Once you‚Äôre able to freely roam Lumiose City, you can reach every store without issue. Make a shopping day of running around the city and trying stuff on. Clothes are no longer gender-locked in Legends: Z-A, either, so you can wear whatever you want. 

You‚Äôll unlock time skip later

Legends: Z-A loves to withhold basic functions for several gameplay hours, including a time skip feature that lets you skip to the night of its day/night cycle. You can only engage in trainer battles during the night, and some wild Pok√©mon only come out when the sun is gone, so there will be times when you wish you could just sit on a bench and wait for nightfall. I can tell you that you will be able to do that eventually, but for the first few hours, you‚Äôll get an in-game warning that it‚Äôs not the time to be resting every time you try and sit down. Once you‚Äôre able to sit on a bench without someone yelling, you‚Äôll be able to skip to evenings or hang out with your Pok√©mon friends on the bench and take photos.

If you haven‚Äôt heard already, Shiny Pok√©mon don‚Äôt despawn

Shiny Pok√©mon just became a lot easier to capture in Legends: Z-A, and it‚Äôs because they no longer despawn. These alternate-colored monsters have a low spawn rate, but in Lumiose City, they‚Äôll stay on the map until you either defeat them or capture them, rather than disappearing as the map refreshes. You can lose a battle, leave a wild zone, or shut the game down entirely, and Shinies will be right where you left them. The hunters have already been exploiting this, but even if you‚Äôre a casual Shiny collector, this will be helpful to your efforts.

More Wild Zones will open as the game progresses

Though you can go just about anywhere in Lumiose City early on, you won‚Äôt find some of your favorite Pok√©mon right off the bat. The Wild Zone areas where Pok√©mon reside will open up as you progress through the story, and later ones will feature monsters you couldn‚Äôt find in the early hours. It does mean that popular Pok√©mon aren‚Äôt available until much later, so if you can‚Äôt find a specific one, just know that more of these zones will appear as you keep going.

Some story missions pause the day/night cycle

This isn‚Äôt a foolproof rule, but it‚Äôs something I noticed when I was running around Lumiose City and hadn‚Äôt received any notifications that the sun was getting low and the metropolis would turn into a battle zone. I had been neglecting a story mission that was set to take place during the day to do some side quests; then, when it dawned on me that time hadn‚Äôt passed, I realized the game world‚Äôs clock had seemingly been frozen until I went to deliver a package to a friend. Sure enough, the sun started setting shortly after I completed the quest. I tested this on a later story mission and noticed the sun was moving as it should, so this isn‚Äôt a universal truth. Just keep in mind that sometimes you might need to finish a story mission before the evening will come, or you can use it to your advantage to keep the sun shining while you run some daytime errands.

Photo mode is essentially a first-person mode

There have been times in Legends: Z-A when I‚Äôve wanted to examine some objects in the environment that were a bit far away in the game‚Äôs usual third-person camera angle. However, if you open photo mode with the minus button, you‚Äôll shift to a first-person perspective that you can walk around in. This is helpful if you want a closer look at an area or museum display. 

You can pick up lost Pok√© Balls from collectors

Part of Lumiose City‚Äôs redevelopment plan is that there are now Pok√© Ball collectors stationed outside the Pok√©mon Center. These guys are keeping the city clean by picking up trash and spare Pok√© Balls that hooligans leave lying around the city. If you throw one of these capturing devices and miss, or a Pok√©mon breaks out of its hold, these guys will be holding onto them at the Center. Before you go stocking up on Pok√© Balls, check in with them to see if they have any of your litter on hand.
